column1: Executive functions are thinking abilities that allow us to achieve our goals. For example
column2: executive functions allow you to stay on task
column6: and refrain from inappropriate actions (like talking back to a teacher). In patients who had experienced TBI more than 4 years ago
column7: we studied an executive function called working memory T
column8: which is the mental workspace that holds information for immediate use. For example
column9: remembering the numbers the teacher writes on the board as you write down the problem in your notebook. Working memory differs from what is called long-term memory
column10: which is what we use to remember events over years. For example
column11: working memory helps us do addition in our heads
column12: long-term memory is what allows us to remember our first day at school.Working memory has three stages: encoding (putting information in)
column14: and retrieval (remembering that information and using it). Usually
column15: people can hold about 3–5 things in working memory at a time. Working memory requires cooperation between regions in both the front and back of the brain. If brain cells in either of these regions are damaged
